HERE IS A SUGGESTION: Put smoke in the surface of the half vortex ring to see if it is close by the air. I'm super curious to see if can be completed by two different fluids.

at 3:11 you compare the vortex in a ring with a tornado but in a tornado, there's low pressure at the top drawing a strong fluid flow up in the core. The rotation is the result of Coriolis force. In a ring, there's no pressure difference driving the core fluid flow, and no Coriolis force. So they really are quite different. There's a mystery as to why they are so persistent. Must be down to the very low viscosity of water preventing energy loss to heat?

I love how this is just "Hey, I'm Dianna, and you're watching physics girl. I want to make a vortex ring in the pool."

the outer edge of the ring rolls on the atmospheric fluid "around" it driven like a wheel on a surface. this action also plows the fluid to the outer boundaries and away from the center of the ring, thus the reverse vector of the center of the toroid has less surface area to roll propelling the ring forward rather than static and spinning in place.

as the ring "thins" (because its expanding, like an ice skater it speeds up which is how its able to sustain its forward motion against the viscosity of its own medium.

if photons could be seen as little smoke rings, then the particle wave duality has a newtonian, or at least "mechanical" explanation

What happens when vortex rings are going through a fluid with different densities?  Suppose you had oil over water, hot water over cold, or fresh water over saline over brine? And you launched a vortex ring so part of it was in each layer? Or you launched it at the bottom and aimed it straight up? At an angle?
I'm guessing the answer is probably "poorly", but I wonder how an attempt at making vortex ring between two fluids of different densities would work out. Say, oil on top of water.
Good video. xD

For some odd reason, it's always more fun to learn stuff from YouTube than from a classroom teacher. Could be that I'm not stressing about a test over the stuff I learn in YouTube videos, or that the stuff in these videos is actually really entertaining. Like in physics class we learn how to do the math on a falling object and see how much force it would expend on whatever it falls upon, or how much energy is necessary to move a 13 Kg object 7 cm up hill or something. Here on YouTube it's like "I did a thing and watch as it does this cool thing!" followed by a quick explanation on how it works. That's how I prefer learning, and from what I can tell, most people do. When presented with something that doesn't make sense the automatic response is to ask a question, these videos often wait just long enough to answer the question. This might not be the best way to learn, but it's much better than trying to make our brains come up with something that I've never would have though of on my own.

Speaking of sound in PVC pipes, last year at work we got two big coils of 5cm flexible pipes that ended up staying pushed to a wall for months because nobody bothered to find a proper storage space for them. And one day I somehow hit one of the ends with the flat of my hand and it takes almost two seconds to hear a pop come out from the other end.
Though the coil was close to 2 meters in diameter, the pipe didn't go around that many times. Makes you realize that the speed of sound is not actually that fast.

I made a 4'x4'x4' plywood cube that would fire 24" diameter smoke rings. It would come out on Halloween and at night I'd use colored flood lights (and strobe lights) to back light the rings. If there was no wind the rings would carry on beyond 75 yards.


The vortex cannon was made of plywood, lumber, re-enforced poly-sheeting (poly roofing material) for the diaphragm, springs, party smoke machine, and a lever-arm so the operator can stand to the side and see the faces of astonished targets of amusement.


Surprisingly, a lazy smoke ring a quite the violent bit of turbulence once you've experience it removing your hat.

I've been thinking more about that resonance tube impossible note thing. You know that sound people make when they're annoyed by something? It's usually spelled "ugh", but it's a bit more complex than that. It's kind kind of a Chewbacca/Llama sound, a bleating and wailing and rumbling vocalization. I think what we're doing there is tuning our internal "tube" to some resonant frequency, and then breathfully vocalizing at that same frequency, causing it to break apart.

I think this phenomenon is also responsible for the "flip" between falsetto and normal voice, and the "breaking" of a voice during male puberty.
